thread.title: Utes vowed to finish against ASU they finally did
thread.title_full: Utes vowed to finish against ASU and they finally did | Deseret News

author: Dirk Facer
title: Utes vowed to finish against ASU they finally did
text:
Unbeaten Utah moves up to No. 3 in the Associated Press poll after knocking off the Sun Devils.
 4 Mins 17 Secs More Coverage Utah notebook: Utes suffer another season-ending injury at tight end Looking back and ahead at Utah's football schedule after win over ASU Utah Utah's usual trength —special teams — is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU Utes report card vs. Arizona State “ We kept going. Everyone was comfortable and confident we would win. Guys stepped up and made big plays.”
Utah QB Travis Wilson
SALT LAKE CITY — Utah’s operative word became a reality in Saturday’s 34-18 win over Arizona State. After losing close contests to the Sun Devils in 2013 and 2014, the Utes were determined to “finish” this time around.
Mission accomplished.
Utah outscored ASU 20-0 over the final 15 minutes to snap an 11-game skid in the matchup with the Sun Devils. In doing so, the Utes became bowl eligible — improving to 6-0 overall and 3-0 in Pac-12 play. They now hold a two-game advantage or greater in the loss column against every team in the South Division.
“We couldn’t ask for a better spot moving into week seven,” said Utah coach Kyle Whittingham. “We’ll celebrate for a day and then get working Monday on our next opponent.”
The Utes, who moved up to No. 3 in this week’s Associated Press poll and remained No. 7 in the coaches rankings, face USC (3-3, 1-2) Saturday in Los Angeles. They do so on the heels of a strong finish against the Sun Devils.
Besides the shutout by the defense, Devontae Booker had touchdown runs of 25 and 62 yards in the fourth quarter. Kicker Andy Phillips made field goals from 43 and 35 yards.
“We kept going. Everyone was comfortable and confident we would win,” said quarterback Travis Wilson. “Guys stepped up and made big plays. I’m really happy with how we finished.”
Wilson wound up completing 26 of 36 passes for 297 yards. He connected on touchdown tosses to Harrison Handley (2 yards) and Kenneth Scott (11 yards).
Booker’s late surge put him at 118 yards rushing by game’s end.
Utah’s defense, though, stole the show. Whittingham said they were collectively the players of the game on a night when the Utes weren’t so special on kick return coverage — surrendering a 100-yard score on a kickoff, as well as a 48-yard punt return and a safety off an illegal forward pass on a kick return.
“That’s not like us,” Whittingham said. “We have to get that fixed.”
Adjustments, however, won’t be needed on defense. Utah held ASU to just 15 yards rushing on 28 carries. The Utes recorded 11 tackles-for-loss, five sacks and two takeaways — a fumble recovery by Tevin Carter and an interception from Cory Butler-Byrd.
“We knew that we had to come in and stop the run,” said linebacker Gionni Paul, who led the Utes with 11 tackles. “We did a great job with that.”
The outcome leaves Utah with some breathing room in the quest for a berth in the Pac-12 Championship Game entering the final six games of the season.
“We knew going in what would happen if we won. That was something big as far as we were concerned,” Wilson said. “We wanted to get a comfortable lead in the standings. We wanted to take care of business against the Sun Devils and fortunately we did.”
EXTRA POINTS: Utah improved to 16-2 when ranked in the Associated Press top 10 . . . Injury updates on tight end Siale Fakailoatonga and linebacker Jared Nor ris are expected Monday . . . Scott and Britain Covey led nine Utah receivers with five catches apiece. Scott finished with a career-high 116 yards receiving . . . Tom Hackett pinned five punts inside the 20 and averaged 46.9 yards over eight kicks. He also made a touchdown-saving tackle on a return . . . Defensive end Hunter Dimick topped the Utes with tackles-for-loss. Norris and defensive end Pita Taumoepenu had two, while Paul, Jason Fanaika, Pasoni Tasini , Kylie Fitts and Lowell Lotulelei were also credited with stops behind the line of scrimmage . . . Taumoepenu had a game-high two sacks. Norris, Tasini, Dimick and Fitts also got to ASU quarterback Mike Bercovici . . . Justin Thomas finished with a game-high three pass breakups. Reggie Porter was credited with two. Marcus Williams , Butler-Byrd and Carter each had one . . . Wilson was sacked five times, three more than he was taken down in the previous five games combined . . . The attendance was 46,192, the 35th consecutive sellout at Rice-Eccles Stadium.
